WRITING.TEXT:
You need to calm down, chap. I was entirely unaware of the fact those quotes were from Wray, given that they're entirely unattributed by the Guardian.
As for "cheating the team" out of elite competition, I guess he forced all the other AP team owners to agree with him, did he?
edit: The article seems to paraphrase, at best, without saying what Wray actually said - given it merely says he used his notes to "comment on the dispute"

there was a reference in an article yesterday about the French only putting second division teams out next year. I'll see if i can find it.
Edit: from the Grauniad: "The Saracens' chairman, Nigel Wray, used his programme notes to comment on the dispute over the future of the Heineken Cup, that it would be second rate without the English and French. That prospect beckons next season, with a meeting on Friday between all the unions involved in Europe, with the exception of the English.
The five remain committed to playing the Heineken Cup next season without the Premiership clubs, but France's commitment would be half-hearted, with some second division teams potentially filling their six places. The four Welsh regions will not take part, which makes it all the more strange that their union is the most gung-ho about what would effectively be a RaboDirect Cup with some forlorn French tinsel."
http://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/jan/18/saracens-connacht-heineken-cup-match-report
Gibraltar getting to Euro 2016 would be some achievement....
fair enough. I thought they'd turned the request down. Shame
Indeed. I think they refused to put Gibraltar Spain on the list, so there's that hilarious possibility hanging there.

Yep, agreed.
As a supporter of a team which aspires to be midtable in the Prem this
"So to put it better, success or 'entertainment' has no bearing on your support of the club."
is absolutely the truth.
Although we did finish second in the league in 1983. And cup runners up in 1984. So there's that.

I might be wrong, but this seems to be Gove vs historians, rather than an internal intellectual controversy. I don't think I've really seen any historian offering any backing to Gove (possibly apart from Max Hastings? And he seems to be a Tory party mouthpiece)

I agree with alot of that, but I think in a more broad sense Gove doesn't really have a basic understanding of the role of education in preparing children, ultimately, for the workforce.
His insistence on exams and rote learning are, in my opinion, a nonsense. We live in a modern world where the single most important skills anyone can have are that of research, of being able to critically dissect a source and to be able to work with others to achieve that.
It's pretty clear that for the most part Gove doesn't have those skills and doesn't want anyone else to, either.

Well, traditionally, at away games nothing was needed to get supporters chanting.
Home atmosphere's been rubbish for a long time and that's in spite of a large group trying to get some noise being made. A smoke bomb won't change that.
Smoke bombs are rubbish. They smell. Atmosphere starts with supporters making some noise, not some tit setting one of those off. A well placed flare, however, is awesome.
Probably the recent obsession with smoke bombs.

Lloyd Doyley. 11 years, 8 managers. Been dropped and repicked by each and every one through sheer persistence and hard work. Not the greatest footballer of all time, but a very good defender and club legend.
He's played under:
Vialli Lewington Boothroyd Rodgers Mackay Dyche Zola Sannini
I love that man.

Used to be either a right back or centre back, with a brief sojourn as a right mid. I enjoyed defending, tbh and I'm neither skillfull or pacey, but based my game on Watford legend Nigel Gibbs - it's about positioning as much as anything. Gave up due to ankles made of biscuits
The idea that Leicester, long masters of the dark arts, have a go at someone else for doing it to them is wonderful

The future jobs thing is almost certain, imho; a number of the players regularly spend time with various big companies in the city personally I don't think it's a terrible thing - after all, surely it's good to give players a post rugby grounding.
I think a number of them have returned/stayed at the club post retirement as well - Richard Hill was working in the Hospitality team has been replaced by Hugh Vyvyan - and as a relative works there confirms, both of them do come in to do work.
His focus has been going forward. Was one of the few bright spots at home to Yeovil, absolutely skinned his man, repeatedly.
*falls over with shock*

Depending on how he rehabs from a serious injury, it's got to be Tommy Hoban for me. Played a fair few games last season as a rookie centre back and was, for the most part, superb. Played like an absolute veteran was neat and tidy on the ball.
Further down the pecking order, some big things are expected of Bernard Mensah I believe Ronny Rosenthal's son is very decent too. (played at youth level for Belgium)
Bellerin's looked excellent in patches for us. Delighted we've got him til the end of the season

WRITING.TITLE: Drove two thirds of the way from Watford to Yeovil today (c.110 miles) only to find out the game was off. Their official Vine shows why....

WRITING.TEXT:
Boxing Day 2000, drove from Watford round to watch Wimbledon (old money) vs Watford in division 1. The previous season we'd been beaten 5-0. It's not the worst drive round; took me 90 minutes or so. Arrive at the ground it's been called off. The only game in the south of England to be cancelled due to frost.
The return trip round the M25 took me over 4 hours due to the M25 being gummed up. Rubbish. I'm never going to Selhurst again.

WRITING.TITLE: The Battle of France, 1940 Dunkirk
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm just reading Anthony Beevor's book on the fall of France the Dunkirk evacuation, and I'm curious to know whether (a) his presentation of the French soldiery as almost entirely cowardly and (b) French general staff as inept and incompetent is actually accurate. Beevor seems to present an almost entirely positive view of British gallantry whilst mentioning the odd example of the French Belgians doing their job. This can't really be the case, can it?
Are there any books written from the French point of view in English that are worth reading?

I guess that's perhaps a good compromise when a keeper being skipper makes it impractical.
On a simple level though, it'd just be nice if refs enforced the dissent law better. A couple of weekends with LOADS of sendings off would be a bit rubbish, but the players would get the message pretty quickly.

It's a fair point, but consider the gains to be made if steps were taken to give the ref a single point of contact and not have a phalanx of players hurling abuse at him.
And if anything, that small gap could help cool things down.

They tried moving it forward in Johnstone Paint Trophy games in the UK. It didn't really work because territorial possession doesn't mean quite as much in football as it does in rugby.
The respect for the ref thing has to be bred from a young age; from youth rugby onwards you're told to go away unless you're the captain. They'd do well to introduce that in football, whilst also making sure refs crack down on dissent properly.
I say that as someone from a working class background who played rugby. Also, i'd argue that rugby union in Wales, Ireland and the West Country of England is very much a working class game....but that's an entirely different argument.
If you're looking for fellow Canadians, I believe the Maple Leaf pub in Covent Garden is popular. Other than that I can't really help :(

WRITING.TEXT:
I was asked to write a piece about the greatest goal I've ever seen scored by my team. Frankly, I struggled a bit - and the one I settled on doesn't have a good quality video on youtube disappointingly - Gifton Noel-Williams volleyed winner against Sunderland in January 1999
So instead, have a selection of my other favourites answer me this: what's the greatest goal you've ever seen?
http://youtu.be/AjunL7v7lNc?t=2m53s - Nick Wright's bicycle kick at Wembley
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H7j2-6Wlk9w - John Eustace vs Coventry

Can rivalries die?
WRITING.TEXT: Context: I'm a Watford supporter. Our historical rivalry is with Luton who are now 4 divisions below us we've not played for seven years. There's been some discussion as to whether or not a rivalry can die amongst our supporters. My opinion: they're irrelevant at the moment, but should they ever get back to a level that's competing with us it's on like donkey-kong....
